fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 vaccines don’t make you a ‘ticking time bomb’
fact_check_explanation_summary: There is no evidence that they cause cancer. In very rare cases, there is a link to blood clots, but the benefits of vaccination generally far outweigh the risks.

fact_check_explanation_title: Spanish Flu pandemic wasn’t caused by a meningitis vaccine
fact_check_explanation_summary: Experts say that there is ‘no way’ that a meningitis vaccine could contribute to starting a flu epidemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake Sky News tweet claims PM drank with foxhound pack
fact_check_explanation_summary: No such story about Boris Johnson and the Berkeley Hunt has been reported.

fact_check_explanation_title: Rubbing hydrogen peroxide over your body every day does not treat cancer
fact_check_explanation_summary: A clip shared on social media makes the potentially harmful claim that hydrogen peroxide rubbed on the skin kills cancer.

fact_check_explanation_title: The ONS has not said only 6,183 people have died of Covid-19
fact_check_explanation_summary: This figure is the number of people in England and Wales who, up to the end of 2021, died of Covid-19 where Covid-19 was the only condition listed on their …

fact_check_explanation_title: PCR inventor Kary Mullis quote doesn’t prove the tests are useless
fact_check_explanation_summary: A quote from the creator of the PCR process, Kary Mullis, is being used to claim PCR testing can find “anything in anybody”.

fact_check_explanation_title: Dan Wootton and David Davis make incorrect claims about Covid-19 deaths
fact_check_explanation_summary: Data from the ONS shows that to the end of September 2021, 17,371 people died in England and Wales of Covid and had no pre-existing conditions.

fact_check_explanation_title: Parents mostly against face masks in classrooms
fact_check_explanation_summary: A recent poll found two thirds of parents of secondary school pupils were against mask wearing in classrooms, but the results may not be representative of parents generally.

fact_check_explanation_title: NHS poster about Bell’s palsy and vaccines is fake
fact_check_explanation_summary: A fake poster warning about vaccines “causing” Bell’s palsy has been shared online.

fact_check_explanation_title: Fake government guidance is wrong about face masks and equality laws
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Instagram misquotes sections of the Equality Act.

fact_check_explanation_title: Covid-19 vaccines haven’t caused an increase in cases and deaths
fact_check_explanation_summary: Misleading headlines shared on social media come from an unpublished study which has been strongly criticised by experts.

fact_check_explanation_title: Photos of swimming pool with social distancing screens is genuine
fact_check_explanation_summary: Photos shared on Facebook show a swimming pool where users have to stand between social distancing screens in the water.
